Interface NativeProgressDialog.Win32IProgressDialog

Namespace: Pietschsoft
Assembly: Konterbont LOD Connector.dll

[Guid("EBBC7C04-315E-11d2-B62F-006097DF5BD4")]
[InterfaceType(ComInterfaceType.InterfaceIsIUnknown)]
public interface Win32IProgressDialog

Methods

| Improve this Doc View Source

HasUserCancelled()

Checks whether the user has canceled the operation.

Declaration
bool HasUserCancelled()
Returns
Type Description
System.Boolean

TRUE if the user has cancelled the operation; otherwise, FALSE.
Remarks

The system does not send a message to the application when the user clicks the Cancel button. You must periodically use this function to poll the progress dialog box object to determine whether the operation has been canceled.

| Improve this Doc View Source

SetAnimation(IntPtr, UInt16)

Specifies an Audio-Video Interleaved (AVI) clip that runs in the dialog box. Note: Note This method is not supported in Windows Vista or later versions.

Declaration
void SetAnimation(IntPtr hInstAnimation, ushort idAnimation)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.IntPtr hInstAnimation

An instance handle to the module from which the AVI resource should be loaded.
System.UInt16 idAnimation

An AVI resource identifier. To create this value, use the MAKEINTRESOURCE macro. The control loads the AVI resource from the module specified by hInstAnimation.
| Improve this Doc View Source

SetCancelMsg(String, Object)

Sets a message to be displayed if the user cancels the operation.

Declaration
void SetCancelMsg(string pwzCancelMsg, object pvResevered)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String pwzCancelMsg

A pointer to a null-terminated Unicode string that contains the message to be displayed.
System.Object pvResevered

Reserved. Set to NULL.
Remarks

Even though the user clicks Cancel, the application cannot immediately call IProgressDialog::StopProgressDialog to close the dialog box. The application must wait until the next time it calls IProgressDialog::HasUserCancelled to discover that the user has canceled the operation. Since this delay might be significant, the progress dialog box provides the user with immediate feedback by clearing text lines 1 and 2 and displaying the cancel message on line 3. The message is intended to let the user know that the delay is normal and that the progress dialog box will be closed shortly. It is typically is set to something like "Please wait while ...".

| Improve this Doc View Source

SetLine(UInt32, String, Boolean, IntPtr)

Displays a message in the progress dialog.

Declaration
void SetLine(uint dwLineNum, string pwzString, bool fCompactPath, IntPtr pvResevered)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 dwLineNum

The line number on which the text is to be displayed. Currently there are three lines—1, 2, and 3. If the PROGDLG_AUTOTIME flag was included in the dwFlags parameter when IProgressDialog::StartProgressDialog was called, only lines 1 and 2 can be used. The estimated time will be displayed on line 3.
System.String pwzString

A null-terminated Unicode string that contains the text.
System.Boolean fCompactPath

TRUE to have path strings compacted if they are too large to fit on a line. The paths are compacted with PathCompactPath.
System.IntPtr pvResevered

Reserved. Set to IntPtr.Zero.
Remarks

This function is typically used to display a message such as "Item XXX is now being processed." typically, messages are displayed on lines 1 and 2, with line 3 reserved for the estimated time.

SetProgress(UInt32, UInt32)

Updates the progress dialog box with the current state of the operation.

Declaration
void SetProgress(uint dwCompleted, uint dwTotal)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 dwCompleted

An application-defined value that indicates what proportion of the operation has been completed at the time the method was called.
System.UInt32 dwTotal

An application-defined value that specifies what value dwCompleted will have when the operation is complete.

| Improve this Doc View Source

Timer(NativeProgressDialog.PDTIMER, Object)

Resets the progress dialog box timer to zero.

Declaration
void Timer(NativeProgressDialog.PDTIMER dwTimerAction, object pvResevered)
Parameters
Type Name Description
NativeProgressDialog.PDTIMER dwTimerAction

Flags that indicate the action to be taken by the timer.
System.Object pvResevered

Reserved. Set to NULL.
Remarks

The timer is used to estimate the remaining time. It is started when your application calls IProgressDialog::StartProgressDialog. Unless your application will start immediately, it should call Timer just before starting the operation. This practice ensures that the time estimates will be as accurate as possible. This method should not be called after the first call to IProgressDialog::SetProgress.
